awd_titl_txt: NRI-Small: Collaborative Research: A Dynamic Bayesian Approach to Real-Time Estimation and Filtering in Grasp Acquisition and Other Contact Tasks
awd_abstract_narration:
Robots cannot currently grasp objects or perform other contact tasks in unstructured environments with speed or reliability.  This project is developing techniques for accurate real-time perception in support of contact tasks.  In the proposed method, sensor data tracks the continuous motions of manipulated objects, while models of the objects are simultaneously updated.  Particle filtering, a kind of Monte-Carlo simulation, ensures consistency of this tracking and updating.

The strongest impact of this work will be in robotic grasping and manipulation.  Because of the synthesis of modeling and probabilistic inference, further impacts can be expected, for example in real-time haptics for telepresence.

por.por_cntn:
Robots cannot currently grasp objects or perform other contact tasks in unstructured environments with speed or reliability. This project developed techniques for accurate real-time perception in support of contact tasks. In our method, sensor data tracks the continuous motions of manipulated objects, while models of the objects are simultaneously updated. Particle filtering, a kind of Monte-Carlo simulation, ensures consistency of this tracking and updating.
Our specific objectives are to develop real-time grasp perception algorithms that will eventually support sophisticated grasp acquisition controllers, which can adjust their actions to accommodate uncertainties arising during the grasping process. We developed the first Bayesian filter that incorporates multibody body dynamics for state prediction that also identifies discrete states, such as whether bodies are in contact or not, and model parameters, such as body masses and friction coefficients. The prediction of discrete contact states does not require tactile sensors.
The results are applicable to manipulation and locomotion systems. The strongest impact of this work is in robotic grasping and manipulation. Because of the synthesis of modeling and probabilistic inference, further impacts can be expected, for example in real-time haptics for telepresence. Also as a result of the project, we train Ph.D. students to work in the field of robotics and organize workshops and write papers to disseminate research results.

Modified by: Siwei Lyu
